reviewText: "Campfire Tales" is a story about four teenagers who, on their way from a concert, get involved in a car crash.  While waiting for someone to stop and help they decide to keep themselves enteratained by telling each other urban legend stories.  It's a wonderful premise however, I guess I'm a bit late to this movie.  It was extremely easy to figure out what was really the case here.  I guess the true moral of this story is that not everything is as it seems.  Still....it's a guilty pleasure.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After running off the road, four young people build a campfire in the ruins of an ancient church building. It's the perfect setting for them to spin three tales of terror. STORY #1- A couple on their honeymoon are attacked by an eeevil creature / demon / man. Can they survive their big night? STORY #2- A little girl is stalked by a lunatic, adult male "friend" that she met on the internet. Things get ugly when the girl's parents go out for the evening, and the babysitting, older sister takes off! Guess who pays a visit? STORY #3- A man on a motorcycle winds up at a remote farmhouse inhabited by a beautiful woman. His dreams soon turn into nightmares when the horrible truth is revealed! CAMPFIRE TALES is a solid entry in the horror anthology category. It's one of my favorites...  P.S.- Nice wrap-around story to boot...

Title: N/A

reviewText: Four teens are stranded off the side of the road after a near collision, where they settle in and decide to tell scary stories while they wait for help to arrive. The first tale pits a newlywed couple against a pack of bloodthirsty creatures on their honeymoon in the woods. The second finds a young girl home alone on Parent/Teacher Night when her pedophilic cyberstalker decides to strike. In the third tale, a cross-country traveler stops at a remote farmhouse after his bike breaks down on the road. Unfortunately for him, the house is home to a beautiful girl, her overprotective father, and the ghosts of her past lovers. Though many of the scares do fall into tired Horror movie cliches, the stories in CAMPFIRE TALES are highly effective while containing a minimal amount of graphic content. They rely far more on character, mood, and atmosphere than cheap shocks or excessive gore. Each of the entries share their roots in urban legends that have been altered slightly for a new twist on the classic tales. Outside of the weak and predictable wrap-around story, the only major flaw the film possesses is in its poor lighting, which makes many of the scenes impossibly dark. CAMPFIRE TALES is an enjoyable late-90's anthology feature that some may find more entertaining than the similar URBAN LEGEND series.-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love it when I rent a movie, and I am not quite sure about it. The cover is no hint to what's inside and the back summary sounds really interesting but I have been burned before. Campfire Tales stars a lot of C and D list celebrities, and sometimes that is what makes a film good, because they don't have to overcome the familiarity factor that the A listers struggle with.We have all sat around in our PJ's or around a campfire and told scary stories. It's a rite of passage, which sadly is dying away due to in part the practice of political correctness. This movie takes that tradition, and tweaks it in a surprisingly creepy and shivery way.I love movies that are broken up into 3-4 smaller vignettes, it gives the filmmakers room to really pack the suspense and action in so they don't have to draw out the story to the point of boring the audience. This one is broken down into three main tales, broken up by scenes of the people telling them around a fire. There are twists and surprises, and it's genuinely scary and creepy. It takes old favorites, and blends them with modern references, with enough nostalgia to allow those of us familiar with the tales to see and feel new things. The most awesome thing about this movie is the lack of computer generated effects, like filmmakers long ago who knew how to scare audiences with shadows, story, and acting this movie excels in the beauty of an "old fashioned" scare. I completely recommend it to anyone who wants to be pleasantly frightened and entertained.
Title: N/A

reviewText: While several other films have come out over the years purporting to address “urban legends”, Campfire Tales goes one better and gives us the stories that we actually remember being told as children (in the 1950’s and 1960’s on up) while we were at summer camp or camping with the Boy Scouts or Girl Scouts.The film addresses the following campfire stories:• The man with hook for a hand; or “Rudy” as I remember it being named• The honeymooners (which in true word of mouth fashion is somewhat different than I remember, but completely well done)• The guy under the bed• The green ribbon (a classic, if ever there was one – I understand this story actually dates back to the 1800’s)All of these stories are very inventively told using a wrap-around storyline about a group of teenagers returning from a rock concert, late at night.Background:Campfire stories – or ghost stories – if you will, were always intended to be cautionary tales; modern Aesop’s Fables or Grimm’s Fairy Tales, if you will. The fact that the same stories my parents heard in their youth are being told today, in some form or another speaks to their indelible effectiveness.Overview:The film is well done – care was taken to cast these characters and each of the story vignettes somehow rings true – there is no over acting or forced dialogue that you might expect with a low budget film of this type. While you may not recognize all of the actors in this film, many have gone on to bigger and better things. I mention this, because the caliber of acting is high – these are not a bunch of no talents.The wrap-around story is particularly well done – these are usually throw away pieces used as merely a vehicle to introduce the main stories (as in Tales from the Crypt (film), Tales of Horror, etc.). That is not the case here. The wrap around story is actually a story with characters possibly more realistic than anything in the vignettes. The acting is particularly good here, especially Christopher Masterson’s understated performance.The VignettesRudy: ExcellentShot in black in white as an homage to its roots back in the 1950’s. Short, but shocking and fun. James Marsden and Amy Smart.The Honeymoon: ExcellentUnderlit, light and airy and fun turns into a dark, creepy story. Honeymooners  (Ron Livingston) who decide to visit, late at night in their rented camper (these were cautionary tales, they didn’t always make practical or logical sense a location where 100 plus years ago a group of pioneers got lost and ended up becoming cannibals. There they run into a very creepy Hawthorne James (Speed) who is perfectly cast. Is he a good guy or a bad guy? You decide. I won’t say more, because – to me – this is the most perfectly told story.The guy under the bed – Very GoodThis is almost exactly as I remember it being told to me – down to the “punchline” as it were. The little girl is perfectly cast and the situation becomes far more logical than the story ever allowed it to be. You may not want to watch this one if you have kids – very very creepy, and yet I think this is the weakest of the stories.The green ribbon – ExcellentThis antiquated story has been effectively updated for the modern audience. Our main character no longer arrives on horseback, but rather by motorcycle. The rest of the elements have been left almost untouched, which makes it all the creepier. The original story was so simple and short, but this telling is more drawn out and unnerving than you can imagine. A classic camp fire tale updated! Glenn Quinn stars.The Wrap Around Story - ExcellentFour teenagers have an accident on the way home from a rock concert and they have to hang out around a campfire while they wait for help to arrive.  Just what kind of help arrives will surprise you. Jay Ferguson, Christine Taylor and Christopher Masterson star.Check this film out and don’t get it confused with the really lousy 1997 film of the same name (Wikipedia doesn’t even have this film listed).
summary: This is one of those scary/creepy movies that you will come back to over time for the sheer pleasure of it.

reviewText: I have to admit I love horror movies and there aren't not very many movies that give me the creeps, freak me out, or scare me. I heard a lot of good reviews about this movie and finally found it here and ordered it. I watched it the night I got it! Usually when I go into a movie with high expectations I am usually disappointed but... this movie was so good! I loved all of the stories in it especially the second one with the little girl and her chat room buddy! This movie really creeped me out and kept me interested the whole time I was watching it. Even the wrap around story that connects the three stories (the story about the teens who crashed and were telling each other the scary stories) was really good. I don't have a single bad thing to say about this movie and I love the actors in this movie as well. I think they did a really good job with it.

reviewText: Campfire Tales is a clever enough anthology retelling some basic, common urban legends. Like most it contains four stories, and the main plot involves some teenagers surrounding a campfire in the woods, deciding to ease their boredom by trying to creep each other out through some short horror stories. Hey, always works on my trips.The first is forgettable and generic focusing on an old urban legend involving the old "hook outside of the car" deal. This one wasn't too long or too great and pretty predictable from already knowing the story.The second ties in with the first as the weakest. Called "The Honeymoon", a couple breaks down in the woods in an RV to find themselves being hunted by a vicious beast. Well technically they pull over to screw around and the beast stops their RV from starting up again. With this cool plot (*cough*) and creepy setting it could have shot out more scares but they didn't try hard enough. It's completely forgettable and every time you think the suspense is going to rise the air gets let out of the tire. While the outside looked promising the inside contained no substance.The third, titled "People can lick too", is about a young girl, being babysat by her sister, who decides to go on to the familiar internet. Stalked by a pedophile, this movie could have shown more going down but it did manage to convey at least one or two deep chilling-to-the-bone scenes. With all that buildup I expected more from the ending but overall more tasty than the first.The fourth, called "The Locket" is where a man goes to an old home for the night and falls for a girl living there. The best of the batch, this one is chilly, intriguing and has one gallop of a twist. I won't spoil details except to say it's a horrific little love tale that stays with you.Finally the film focuses on the camp kids and surprised the hell out of me. I can't give anything else or it would spoil the whole thing. But it's worth finishing to the end to find out.After ending with a conclusion hard to forget and instilling some dark scenes into my horror-soaked brain, this manages to stay at the top of the anthology chart but is slightly watered down. Think of a great movie intended more for TV and not to expect much in the way of gore and adult-themed scares.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Campfire Tales" is a decent low-budget horror movie. The concept is really good; A group of teens who have a car accident, ride out the night by telling each other urban legends at an old, abandoned church. Unfortunitely, not all of the stories work. The brief opener, "The Hook" is beyond hokey, & "People Lick Too" is just plain uncomfortable to watch. "The Boyfriend's Death" is far superior, and is genuinely unsettling. "The Locket" has it's moments, and ends up enjoyable if for nothing else then the final scene (which was over the top and funny, in a b-movie kind of way). The film itself, has a really nice twist, which is rare in horror movies (or any movies these days, when the ending if often a forgone conclusion). Overall, not the best, but "Campfire Tales" definitely has it's moments which make it worth seeing.

reviewText: As the evenings grow cooler and the football season takes flight, we feel the need to increase our horror movie intake to high levels of consumption. With a genre consisting of so many themes it can often be hard to decide on a pick. Typically we'll seek out some nice low budget 80's-90's flick that could either be really good or really bad. Today lead us to a film from 1997 known as Campfire Tales. Naturally we were intrigued by the fact it's a horror film comprised of 3 horror shorts. This type of feature is always one of our favorites. It has a few more noteworthy actors then we typically care to see in a film, but it seemed cheap enough. Plus the thought of getting to see Peter Gibbons outside the Inetech office was a very noble idea. Now most would consider this to be a pretty B-grade cast, but when you're used to Don Swayze and Chad McQueen then this cast looks like elite group of actors.The film opens up with some kids cruising around a dark winding highway. Naturally the driver is a real cowboy and sends the car flying off the road down into the woods. They all assemble, seemingly unharmed, and wind up waiting around for someone to show up. Remember this was before cell phones were glued to everyone's faces. As they wait they begin to tell scary stories. Which is of course what you want to do after flying off the highway and stranded in the middle of nowhere. They begin to tell three stories that are pretty decent, yet never really pack any punch. The first story stars Ron Livingston who takes his new bride in an RV out to a desolate canyon. While there they are stalked by some man-creatures after their RV breaks down. This was the best story by far. The next is something straight out of a To Catch a Predator episode, and would have been good if Chris Hansen made a guest cameo. The last was a ghost type story that started out strong but really didn't deliver too much in the end. After all this we go back to the kids to learn that they've really been dead all along...ooo spooky.We wanted to love Campfire Tales, as it comes from our favorite era, and embodies the short story concept we always prefer. However the stories were lacking. All of them started off with the goods but somewhat unraveled by the end. They never really hit you with the front. When the story would end you'd say "that's it?" fully expecting there to have been a more intense conclusion. Now this doesn't mean it wasn't an enjoyable viewing. It was actually worth one watch, but nothing more then that. It doesn't quite compete with say a Creepshow or Tales From the Darkside. To really work this one up to a 5 star event they should have told the story of Santa and the football pants. This tragic tale is horrific and hilarious in one perfect storm of B. That would have made this movie perfect.

reviewText: This is, simply put, a strong contender for the title of best horror anthology movie ever made.  With high-level production values throughout and a series of framing sequences that enhances the overall flow of the whole better than any anthology I can think of, "Campfire Tales" offers a pretty diverse mix of spooky/horror/suspense shorts.  The most disturbing and uncomfortable of the tales involves a human predator stalking a family, with his primary target seeming to be the child.  Given the subject matter, I think it was smart of the filmmakers to have regned this segment in a bit, relying on suspense and implied creepiness rather than anything overt or onscreen violent.  In 99.5% of horror fiction I don't think there's any such thing as going too far, but in a case (not to give too much away) like this it could have come off tasteless if not handled with care.  In the other segments of the movie the tales are given freer reign in terms of carnage and sexuality, resulting in a variety of moods.  The plots of the stories are not groundbreaking - and that's in fact the point, they're designed to come off as familiar ideas that the individual teller around the likes of a campfire would put their own twists and spins on - with themes like the 'hook-handed killer' being trotted out.  Despite the familiarity of the stories, the twists and nuances are there to keep them fresh and they're simply done better than most other explorations of similar ground (although the 'hook-handed killer' motif was, obviously, handled to perfection in the first two "Candyman" movies).  Combined, the various segments and the 'framing' story run the gamut through scariness, appropriate humor, sexiness, eerie atmospherics, dark psychological and 'unexpected turns' territoty, with occasional dashes of 'supernatural fantasy' type moments added in as well for an even better blend.  The movie certainly isn't hurt by having one of the best-looking ensembles of female cast members either.  All tolled, it rises to the level of an anthology that achieves true greatness.
summary: An Outstanding Round Of Horror Tales

reviewText: I don't understand reviewers who call this film "a lost gem" or "smart" or even "a strong contender for the title of best horror anthology movie ever made."REALLY? The BEST horror anthology ever made? Even a contender?* Better than the classic 1945 British ghost anthology,Dead of Night, which essentially INVENTED the horror anthology format?* Better than Amicus's long string of horror anthology classics, such asAsylumor 1972'sTales from the Crypt, which essentially POPULARIZED the horror anthology format?* Better than Stephen King and George Romero'sCreepshow, which reconnected the format to its comic book roots through the use of primary colors and canted panels?* Better thanTrick 'r Treat, with its beautiful pastel, autumnal colors and authentically Halloween-rooted themes?I could list other great horror anthology films, but you get the point.Now, CAMPFIRE TALES is not bad. It has a talented cast, some of whom went on to great things (e.g. Ron Livingston ofOffice Space). It's a solid, entertaining horror anthology -- but it's hardly on top of the pack.CAMPFIRE TALES's three tales are nothing special, even mostly unoriginal -- and I disagree with reviewers who say "that's the point" because "this is a return to old-fashioned scares." Not that old-fashioned scares are bad, but there are plenty of horror anthology films with old-fashioned scares.CAMPFIRE TALES's strong (though hardly unique) points include a talented and attractive cast, some good scares, competent production values, and a surprising -- and surprisingly poignant -- ending, with a message about drinking and driving.But this is hardly a seminal horror anthology film.Also released about the same time wasGrim Prairie Tales, which shares the above strengths, but has more original tales. (It's a horror western, for those who enjoy that blend.)
